title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: using nycflights13 datasets document. installed package, please following: 5 datasets package: airlines airports flights planes weather want quickly visualize structure , may following: may also try plot_str(data_list, type = "r") radial network. Now let’s merge tables together robust dataset later sections.
code: install.packages("nycflights13") library(nycflights13) library(DataExplorer) data_list <- list(airlines, airports, flights, planes, weather) plot_str(data_list) merge_airlines <- merge(flights, airlines, by = "carrier", all.x = TRUE) merge_planes <- merge(merge_airlines, planes, by = "tailnum", all.x = TRUE, suffixes = c("_flights", "_planes")) merge_airports_origin <- merge(merge_planes, airports, by.x = "origin", by.y = "faa", all.x = TRUE, suffixes = c("_carrier", "_origin")) final_data <- merge(merge_airports_origin, airports, by.x = "dest", by.y = "faa", all.x = TRUE, suffixes = c("_origin", "_dest"))

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: Exploratory data analysis process get know data, can generate test hypothesis. Visualization techniques usually applied. get introduced newly created dataset: visualize table (light analysis):  immediately notice surprises: 0.3% complete rows: means 0.3% rows completely missing! 5.7% missing observations: Given 0.3% complete rows, 5.7% total missing observations. Missing values definitely creating problems. Let’s take look missing profiles.
code: introduce(final_data) plot_intro(final_data)

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: Real-world data messy, can simply use plot_missing function visualize missing profile feature.  chart, speed variable mostly missing, probably informative. Looks like found culprit 0.3% complete rows. Let’s drop : Note: may store missing data profile profile_missing(final_data) additional analysis.
code: plot_missing(final_data) final_data <- drop_columns(final_data, "speed")

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: visualize frequency distributions discrete features:  Upon closer inspection manufacturer variable, hard identify following duplications: AIRBUS AIRBUS INDUSTRIE CANADAIR CANADAIR LTD MCDONNELL DOUGLAS, MCDONNELL DOUGLAS AIRCRAFT CO MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORPORATION Let’s clean look manufacturer distribution :  Feature dst_origin, tzone_origin, year_flights tz_origin contains 1 value, drop : Frequently, beneficial look bi-variate frequency distribution. example, look discrete features arr_delay:  resulting distribution looks quite different regular frequency distribution. may choose break frequencies discrete variable:
code: plot_bar(final_data) ## 5 columns ignored with more than 50 categories. ## dest: 105 categories ## tailnum: 4044 categories ## time_hour: 6936 categories ## model: 128 categories ## name: 102 categories final_data[which(final_data$manufacturer == "AIRBUS INDUSTRIE"),]$manufacturer <- "AIRBUS" final_data[which(final_data$manufacturer == "CANADAIR LTD"),]$manufacturer <- "CANADAIR" final_data[which(final_data$manufacturer %in% c("MCDONNELL DOUGLAS AIRCRAFT CO", "MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORPORATION")),]$manufacturer <- "MCDONNELL DOUGLAS"  plot_bar(final_data$manufacturer) final_data <- drop_columns(final_data, c("dst_origin", "tzone_origin", "year_flights", "tz_origin")) plot_bar(final_data, with = "arr_delay") ## 5 columns ignored with more than 50 categories. ## dest: 105 categories ## tailnum: 4044 categories ## time_hour: 6936 categories ## model: 128 categories ## name: 102 categories plot_bar(final_data, by = "origin") ## 5 columns ignored with more than 50 categories. ## dest: 105 categories ## tailnum: 4044 categories ## time_hour: 6936 categories ## model: 128 categories ## name: 102 categories

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: visualize distributions continuous features:  Immediately, observe datetime features treated, e.g., concatenating year, month day form date, /adding hour minute form datetime. purpose vignette, go deep analytical tasks. However, treat following features based output histograms. Set flight categorical, since flight number mathematical meaning: Remove year_flights tz_origin since one value:
code: plot_histogram(final_data) final_data <- update_columns(final_data, "flight", as.factor) final_data <- drop_columns(final_data, c("year_flights", "tz_origin"))

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: Quantile-Quantile plot way visualize deviation specific probability distribution. analyzing plots, often beneficial apply mathematical transformation (log) models like linear regression. , can use plot_qq function. default, compares normal distribution. Note: function take long time many observations, may choose specify appropriate sampled_rows:  chart, air_time, distance seats seems skewed tails. Let’s apply simple log transformation plot .  distribution looks better now! necessary, may also view QQ plot another feature:
code: qq_data <- final_data[, c("arr_delay", "air_time", "distance", "seats")]  plot_qq(qq_data, sampled_rows = 1000L) log_qq_data <- update_columns(qq_data, 2:4, function(x) log(x + 1))  plot_qq(log_qq_data[, 2:4], sampled_rows = 1000L) qq_data <- final_data[, c("name_origin", "arr_delay", "air_time", "distance", "seats")]  plot_qq(qq_data, by = "name_origin", sampled_rows = 1000L)

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: visualize correlation heatmap non-missing features:  may also choose visualize discrete/continuous features :
code: plot_correlation(na.omit(final_data), maxcat = 5L) ## 11 features with more than 5 categories ignored! ## dest: 100 categories ## tailnum: 3246 categories ## carrier: 16 categories ## flight: 3773 categories ## time_hour: 6642 categories ## name_carrier: 16 categories ## manufacturer: 24 categories ## model: 121 categories ## engine: 6 categories ## name: 100 categories ## tzone_dest: 7 categories plot_correlation(na.omit(final_data), type = "c") plot_correlation(na.omit(final_data), type = "d")

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: can always plot_prcomp(na.omit(final_data)) directly, PCA works better cleaner data. perform visualize PCA selected features:
code: pca_df <- na.omit(final_data[, c("origin", "dep_delay", "arr_delay", "air_time", "year_planes", "seats")])  plot_prcomp(pca_df, variance_cap = 0.9, nrow = 2L, ncol = 2L)

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: Missing values may meanings feature. imputation methods, may also set logical values. example, discrete features, may want group missing values new category. continuous features, may want set missing values known number based existing knowledge. DataExplorer, can done set_missing. function automatically matches argument either discrete continuous features, .e., specify number, missing continuous values set number. specify string, missing discrete values set string. supply , types set.
code: ## Return data.frame final_df <- set_missing(final_data, list(0L, "unknown")) ## Column [dep_time]: Set 8255 missing values to 0 ## Column [dep_delay]: Set 8255 missing values to 0 ## Column [arr_time]: Set 8713 missing values to 0 ## Column [arr_delay]: Set 9430 missing values to 0 ## Column [air_time]: Set 9430 missing values to 0 ## Column [year_planes]: Set 57912 missing values to 0 ## Column [engines]: Set 52606 missing values to 0 ## Column [seats]: Set 52606 missing values to 0 ## Column [lat_dest]: Set 7602 missing values to 0 ## Column [lon_dest]: Set 7602 missing values to 0 ## Column [alt_dest]: Set 7602 missing values to 0 ## Column [tz_dest]: Set 7602 missing values to 0 ## Column [tailnum]: Set 2512 missing values to unknown ## Column [type]: Set 52606 missing values to unknown ## Column [manufacturer]: Set 52606 missing values to unknown ## Column [model]: Set 52606 missing values to unknown ## Column [engine]: Set 52606 missing values to unknown ## Column [name]: Set 7602 missing values to unknown ## Column [dst_dest]: Set 7602 missing values to unknown ## Column [tzone_dest]: Set 7602 missing values to unknown plot_missing(final_df) ## Update data.table by reference # library(data.table) # final_dt <- data.table(final_data) # set_missing(final_dt, list(0L, "unknown")) # plot_missing(final_dt)

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: bar charts , observed number discrete features sparse categorical distributions. Sometimes, want group low-frequency categories new bucket, reduce number categories reasonable range. group_category work. Take manufacturer feature example, suppose want group long tail another category. try bottom 20% (count) first: can see, manufacturer shrinked 4 categories, .e., AIRBUS, BOEING, EMBRAER, . like threshold, may specify update = TRUE update original dataset:  Instead shrinking categories frequency, may also group categories another continuous metric. example, want bucket carrier bottom 20% distance traveled, may following: Similarly, like , may add update = TRUE update original dataset.
code: group_category(data = final_data, feature = "manufacturer", threshold = 0.2) ##   manufacturer   cnt       pct   cum_pct ## 1       AIRBUS 88193 0.2618744 0.2618744 ## 2       BOEING 82912 0.2461933 0.5080677 ## 3      EMBRAER 66068 0.1961779 0.7042456 final_df <- group_category(data = final_data, feature = "manufacturer", threshold = 0.2, update = TRUE) plot_bar(final_df$manufacturer) group_category(data = final_data, feature = "name_carrier", threshold = 0.2, measure = "distance") ##             name_carrier      cnt       pct   cum_pct ## 1  United Air Lines Inc. 89705524 0.2561422 0.2561422 ## 2   Delta Air Lines Inc. 59507317 0.1699153 0.4260575 ## 3        JetBlue Airways 58384137 0.1667082 0.5927657 ## 4 American Airlines Inc. 43864584 0.1252495 0.7180152 final_df <- group_category(data = final_data, feature = "name_carrier", threshold = 0.2, measure = "distance", update = TRUE) plot_bar(final_df$name_carrier)

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: transform data binary format (ML algorithms can pick ), dummify job. function preserves original data structure, eligible discrete features turned binary format. Note maxcat argument. discrete feature categories maxcat, dummified. result, returned untouched.
code: plot_str(   list(     "original" = final_data,     "dummified" = dummify(final_data, maxcat = 5L)   ) ) ## 11 features with more than 5 categories ignored! ## dest: 105 categories ## tailnum: 4044 categories ## carrier: 16 categories ## flight: 3844 categories ## time_hour: 6936 categories ## name_carrier: 16 categories ## manufacturer: 32 categories ## model: 128 categories ## engine: 7 categories ## name: 102 categories ## tzone_dest: 8 categories

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: viewing feature distribution, often want drop features insignificant. example, features like dst_dest mostly one value, doesn’t provide valuable information. can use drop_columns quickly drop features. function takes either names column indices.
code: identical(   drop_columns(final_data, c("dst_dest", "tzone_dest")),   drop_columns(final_data, c(36, 37)) ) ## [1] TRUE

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: quickly update many features treatment, may use update_columns. common use case set features different type, e.g., continuous discrete. quickly set time related features discrete: may also use function transform selected features customized function:
code: temporal_features <- c("month", "day", "hour", "minute", "tz_dest") final_data <- update_columns(final_data, temporal_features, as.factor) str(final_data[, c("month", "day", "hour", "minute", "tz_dest")]) ## 'data.frame':    336776 obs. of  5 variables: ##  $ month  : Factor w/ 12 levels "1","2","3","4",..: 5 10 12 5 12 8 7 7 5 8 ... ##  $ day    : Factor w/ 31 levels "1","2","3","4",..: 14 29 19 30 7 25 12 1 15 26 ... ##  $ hour   : Factor w/ 20 levels "1","5","6","7",..: 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 ... ##  $ minute : Factor w/ 60 levels "0","1","2","3",..: 2 1 2 2 2 8 8 8 2 8 ... ##  $ tz_dest: Factor w/ 6 levels "-10","-9","-8",..: 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 4 ... bin_seat <- function(x) cut(x, breaks = c(0L, 50L, 100L, 150L, 200L, 500L)) transformed_data <- update_columns(final_data, "seats", bin_seat)  plot_bar(transformed_data$seats)

title: Introduction to DataExplorer
text: organize data profiling statistics report, may use create_report function. run EDA functions output html file. maximize usage function, always supply response variable (applicable) automate various bivariate analyses. example, may also customize individual section using configure_report function. returns specified arguments list, passed .call invoked. 3 types arguments function: switches (add_*): turn /section arguments (*_args): customize section global settings (global_*): global theme settings turn sections set global theme: output can passed directly config argument create_repot, e.g., configure report without using configure_report function, may edit template pass directly config argument:
code: create_report(final_data) create_report(final_data, y = "arr_delay") configure_report(   add_plot_str = FALSE,   add_plot_qq = FALSE,   add_plot_prcomp = FALSE,   add_plot_boxplot = FALSE,   add_plot_scatterplot = FALSE,   global_ggtheme = quote(theme_minimal(base_size = 14)) ) ## $introduce ## list() ##  ## $plot_intro ## $plot_intro$ggtheme ## theme_minimal(base_size = 14) ##  ## $plot_intro$theme_config ## list() ##  ##  ## $plot_missing ## $plot_missing$ggtheme ## theme_minimal(base_size = 14) ##  ## $plot_missing$theme_config ## list() ##  ##  ## $plot_histogram ## $plot_histogram$ggtheme ## theme_minimal(base_size = 14) ##  ## $plot_histogram$theme_config ## list() ##  ##  ## $plot_bar ## $plot_bar$ggtheme ## theme_minimal(base_size = 14) ##  ## $plot_bar$theme_config ## list() ##  ##  ## $plot_correlation ## $plot_correlation$ggtheme ## theme_minimal(base_size = 14) ##  ## $plot_correlation$theme_config ## list() ##  ## $plot_correlation$cor_args ## $plot_correlation$cor_args$use ## [1] "pairwise.complete.obs" config <- configure_report(   add_plot_str = FALSE,   add_plot_qq = FALSE,   add_plot_prcomp = FALSE,   add_plot_boxplot = FALSE,   add_plot_scatterplot = FALSE,   global_ggtheme = quote(theme_minimal(base_size = 14)) ) create_report(final_data, config = config) config <- list(   "introduce" = list(),   "plot_intro" = list(),   "plot_str" = list(     "type" = "diagonal",     "fontSize" = 35,     "width" = 1000,     "margin" = list("left" = 350, "right" = 250)   ),   "plot_missing" = list(),   "plot_histogram" = list(),   "plot_density" = list(),   "plot_qq" = list(sampled_rows = 1000L),   "plot_bar" = list(),   "plot_correlation" = list("cor_args" = list("use" = "pairwise.complete.obs")),   "plot_prcomp" = list(),   "plot_boxplot" = list(),   "plot_scatterplot" = list(sampled_rows = 1000L) ) create_report(final_data, config = config)

title: Automate Data Exploration and Treatment
text: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) initial important phase data analysis/predictive modeling. process, analysts/modelers first look data, thus generate relevant hypotheses decide next steps. However, EDA process hassle times. R package aims automate data handling visualization, users focus studying data extracting insights.

title: Automate Data Exploration and Treatment
text: package can installed directly CRAN. However, latest stable version () found GitHub, installed using devtools package. like install latest development version, may install develop branch.
code: install.packages("DataExplorer") if (!require(devtools)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("boxuancui/DataExplorer") if (!require(devtools)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("boxuancui/DataExplorer", ref = "develop")

title: Automate Data Exploration and Treatment
text: package extremely easy use. Almost everything done one line code. Please refer package manuals information. may also find package vignettes .

title: Automate Data Exploration and Treatment
text: get report airquality dataset: get report diamonds dataset response variable price:
code: library(DataExplorer) create_report(airquality) library(ggplot2) create_report(diamonds, y = "price")

title: Automate Data Exploration and Treatment
text: Instead running create_report, may also run function individually analysis, e.g.,
code: ## View basic description for airquality data introduce(airquality) ## Plot basic description for airquality data plot_intro(airquality) ## View missing value distribution for airquality data plot_missing(airquality) ## Left: frequency distribution of all discrete variables plot_bar(diamonds) ## Right: `price` distribution of all discrete variables plot_bar(diamonds, with = "price") ## View frequency distribution by a discrete variable plot_bar(diamonds, by = "cut") ## View histogram of all continuous variables plot_histogram(diamonds) ## View estimated density distribution of all continuous variables plot_density(diamonds) ## View quantile-quantile plot of all continuous variables plot_qq(diamonds) ## View quantile-quantile plot of all continuous variables by feature `cut` plot_qq(diamonds, by = "cut") ## View overall correlation heatmap plot_correlation(diamonds) ## View bivariate continuous distribution based on `cut` plot_boxplot(diamonds, by = "cut") ## Scatterplot `price` with all other continuous features plot_scatterplot(split_columns(diamonds)$continuous, by = "price", sampled_rows = 1000L) ## Visualize principal component analysis plot_prcomp(diamonds, maxcat = 5L) #> 2 features with more than 5 categories ignored! #> color: 7 categories #> clarity: 8 categories

title: Automate Data Exploration and Treatment
text: make quick updates data:
code: ## Group bottom 20% `clarity` by frequency group_category(diamonds, feature = "clarity", threshold = 0.2, update = TRUE)  ## Group bottom 20% `clarity` by `price` group_category(diamonds, feature = "clarity", threshold = 0.2, measure = "price", update = TRUE)  ## Dummify diamonds dataset dummify(diamonds) dummify(diamonds, select = "cut")  ## Set values for missing observations df <- data.frame("a" = rnorm(260), "b" = rep(letters, 10)) df[sample.int(260, 50), ] <- NA set_missing(df, list(0L, "unknown"))  ## Update columns update_columns(airquality, c("Month", "Day"), as.factor) update_columns(airquality, 1L, function(x) x^2)  ## Drop columns drop_columns(diamonds, 8:10) drop_columns(diamonds, "clarity")

Default TRUE. add_plot_histogram add plot_histogram? Default TRUE. add_plot_density add plot_density? Default FALSE. add_plot_qq add plot_qq? Default TRUE. add_plot_bar add plot_bar? Default TRUE. add_plot_correlation add plot_correlation? Default TRUE. add_plot_prcomp add plot_prcomp? Default TRUE. add_plot_boxplot add plot_boxplot? title: Configure report template — configure_report
text: Individual settings overwrite global settings. example: plot_intro_args ggtheme set theme_light() global_ggtheme set theme_gray(), theme_light() used. setting global themes using global_ggtheme, please pass unevaluated call theme function, e.g., quote(theme_light()).

title: Create report — create_report
text: function creates data profiling report.

title: Create report — create_report
code: create_report(   data,   output_format = html_document(toc = TRUE, toc_depth = 6, theme = "yeti"),   output_file = "report.html",   output_dir = getwd(),   y = NULL,   config = configure_report(),   report_title = "Data Profiling Report",   ... )

title: Create report — create_report
text: data input data output_format output format render. Default html_document(toc = TRUE, toc_depth = 6, theme = "yeti"). output_file output file name render. Default "report.html". output_dir output directory report render. Default user's current directory. y name response variable . Response variables passed appropriate plotting functions automatically. config report configuration generated configure_report. report_title report title. Default "Data Profiling Report". ... arguments passed render.

title: Create report — create_report
text: config named list evaluated create_report. name exactly match function name. , function corresponding content added report. want include certain functions/content, add config. configure_report generates default template. may customize content using function. function arguments passed .call list.

title: Create report — create_report
text: y plot_prcomp present, y removed plot_prcomp. multiple options function, plotted. example, create_report(..., y = "", config = list("plot_bar" = list("" = "b"))) create 3 bar charts: regular frequency bar chart bar chart aggregated response variable "" bar chart aggregated `` variable "b"`

title: Create report — create_report
code: if (FALSE) { # Create report create_report(iris) create_report(airquality, y = "Ozone")  # Load library library(ggplot2) library(data.table) library(rmarkdown)  # Set some missing values diamonds2 <- data.table(diamonds) for (j in 5:ncol(diamonds2)) {   set(diamonds2,       i = sample.int(nrow(diamonds2), sample.int(nrow(diamonds2), 1)),       j,       value = NA_integer_) }  # Create customized report for diamonds2 dataset create_report(   data = diamonds2,   output_format = html_document(toc = TRUE, toc_depth = 6, theme = "flatly"),   output_file = "report.html",   output_dir = getwd(),   y = "price",   config = configure_report(     add_plot_prcomp = TRUE,     plot_qq_args = list("by" = "cut", sampled_rows = 1000L),     plot_bar_args = list("with" = "carat"),     plot_correlation_args = list("cor_args" = list("use" = "pairwise.complete.obs")),     plot_boxplot_args = list("by" = "cut"),     global_ggtheme = quote(theme_light())   ) )  ## Configure report without `configure_report` config <- list(   "introduce" = list(),   "plot_intro" = list(),   "plot_str" = list(     "type" = "diagonal",     "fontSize" = 35,     "width" = 1000,     "margin" = list("left" = 350, "right" = 250)   ),   "plot_missing" = list(),   "plot_histogram" = list(),   "plot_density" = list(),   "plot_qq" = list(sampled_rows = 1000L),   "plot_bar" = list(),   "plot_correlation" = list("cor_args" = list("use" = "pairwise.complete.obs")),   "plot_prcomp" = list(),   "plot_boxplot" = list(),   "plot_scatterplot" = list(sampled_rows = 1000L) ) }

title: Drop selected variables — drop_columns
code: # Load packages library(data.table)  # Generate data dt <- data.table(sapply(setNames(letters, letters), function(x) {assign(x, rnorm(10))})) dt2 <- copy(dt)  # Drop variables by name names(dt) #>  [1] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e" "f" "g" "h" "i" "j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o" "p" "q" "r" "s" #> [20] "t" "u" "v" "w" "x" "y" "z" drop_columns(dt, letters[2L:25L]) names(dt) #> [1] "a" "z"  # Drop variables by column position names(dt2) #>  [1] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e" "f" "g" "h" "i" "j" "k" "l" "m" "n" "o" "p" "q" "r" "s" #> [20] "t" "u" "v" "w" "x" "y" "z" drop_columns(dt2, seq(2, 25)) names(dt2) #> [1] "a" "z"  # Return from non-data.table input df <- data.frame(sapply(setNames(letters, letters), function(x) {assign(x, rnorm(10))})) drop_columns(df, letters[2L:25L]) #>              a           z #> 1   0.14967935 -1.23891024 #> 2  -1.43332110  2.65489833 #> 3  -0.01030332 -0.15691719 #> 4  -0.21223603 -0.42349012 #> 5  -0.90634018 -0.19838706 #> 6  -2.10215248 -0.89480241 #> 7   1.89336046  0.90426912 #> 8  -0.96812584  0.07964921 #> 9  -0.10260304 -1.25882722 #> 10  0.23995957  1.02568511

title: Visualize principal component analysis — plot_prcomp
text: Discrete features dummify-ed first passing prcomp. Missing values may create issues prcomp. Consider na.omit input data first. Features zero variance dropped.

title: Visualize principal component analysis — plot_prcomp
code: plot_prcomp(na.omit(airquality), nrow = 2L, ncol = 2L)

title: Plot QQ plot — plot_qq
text: data input data feature name broken . selecting continuous feature, grouped 5 equal ranges, otherwise, existing categories discrete feature. Default NULL. sampled_rows number rows sample data many rows. Default rows, means sample. geom_qq_args list arguments geom_qq geom_qq_line_args list arguments geom_qq_line title plot title ggtheme complete ggplot2 themes. Default theme_gray. theme_config list configurations passed theme nrow number rows per page. Default 3. ncol number columns per page. Default 3. parallel enable parallel? Default FALSE.

title: Plot QQ plot — plot_qq

title: Plot QQ plot — plot_qq
code: plot_qq(iris)  plot_qq(iris, by = "Species", ncol = 2L)   plot_qq(   data = airquality,   geom_qq_args = list(na.rm = TRUE),   geom_qq_line_args = list(na.rm = TRUE) )

title: Create scatterplot for all features — plot_scatterplot
text: data input data feature name fixed sampled_rows number rows sample data many rows. Default rows, means sample. geom_point_args list arguments geom_point geom_jitter_args list arguments geom_jitter. empty, geom_jitter added. scale_x scale original x axis (coord_flip). See scale_x_continuous options. Default NULL. scale_y scale original y axis (coord_flip). See scale_y_continuous options. Default NULL. title plot title ggtheme complete ggplot2 themes. default theme_gray. theme_config list configurations passed theme. nrow number rows per page ncol number columns per page parallel enable parallel? Default FALSE.

title: Create scatterplot for all features — plot_scatterplot
text: invisibly return named list ggplot objects

title: Create scatterplot for all features — plot_scatterplot
code: plot_scatterplot(iris, by = "Species")   # Plot skewed data on log scale set.seed(1) skew <- data.frame(replicate(5L, rbeta(1000, 1, 5000))) plot_scatterplot(skew, by = "X5", ncol = 2L)  plot_scatterplot(skew, by = "X5", scale_x = "log10", scale_y = "log10", ncol = 2L)   # Plot with `geom_jitter` plot_scatterplot(iris, by = "Species", geom_jitter_args = list(width = NULL)) # Turn on with default settings  plot_scatterplot(iris, by = "Species", geom_jitter_args = list(width = 0.1, height = 0.1))   if (FALSE) { # Customize themes library(ggplot2) plot_scatterplot(   data = mpg,   by = "hwy",   geom_point_args = list(size = 1L),   theme_config = list("axis.text.x" = element_text(angle = 90)),   ncol = 4L ) }

title: Visualize data structure — plot_str
text: Visualize data structures D3 network graph

title: Visualize data structure — plot_str
code: plot_str(   data,   type = c("diagonal", "radial"),   max_level = NULL,   print_network = TRUE,   ... )

title: Visualize data structure — plot_str
text: data input data type type network diagram. Defaults diagonalNetwork. max_level integer threshold nested level visualized. Minimum 1 nested level defaults . print_network logical indicating network graph plotted. Defaults TRUE. ... arguments passed plotting functions. See diagonalNetwork radialNetwork.

title: Visualize data structure — plot_str
text: input data structure nested list. transformed json format JSON packages.

title: Visualize data structure — plot_str
code: ## Visualize structure of iris dataset plot_str(iris)  ## Visualize object with radial network plot_str(rep(list(rep(list(mtcars), 6)), 4), type = "r")  ## Generate complicated data object obj <- list(   "a" = list(iris, airquality, list(mtcars = mtcars, USArrests = USArrests)),   "b" = list(list(ts(1:10, frequency = 4))),   "c" = lm(rnorm(5) ~ seq(5)),   "d" = lapply(1:5, function(x) return(as.function(function(y) y + 1))) ) ## Visualize data object with diagnal network plot_str(obj, type = "d") ## Visualize only top 2 nested levels plot_str(obj, type = "d", max_level = 2)

BarDiscrete -> plot_bar CollapseCategory -> group_category CorrelationContinuous-> plot_correlation(..., type = "continuous") CorrelationDiscrete-> plot_correlation(..., type = "discrete") DensityContinuous -> plot_density DropVar -> drop_columns GenerateReport -> create_report HistogramContinuous -> plot_histogram PlotMissing -> plot_missing PlotStr -> plot_str SetNaTo -> set_missing SplitColType -> split_columns #52: Combined CorrelationContinuous CorrelationDiscrete one function, added option view correlation features . Optimized layout multiple plots.
